They will be keen to climb the standings as the tournament progresses.Next up, Delhi Capitals face a tough test against Gujarat Titans, while Chennai Super Kings look to bounce back against Mumbai Indians. As the race for playoffs intensifies, every match and NRR will matter.

Stubbs needed no second invitation ‚Äî he launched Sandeep into the stands, sealing a dramatic win for Delhi Capitals.It was their first win at home this season, and it took them right back to the top of the table. As the players celebrated, the ‚ÄòDilli re, Roar Macha!‚Äô anthem echoed through the Kotla ‚Äî a perfect end to a pulsating night of cricket.Tension was palpable in the Rajasthan Royals dugout. Sanju Samson wore a frustrated look behind the stumps as Sandeep Sharma ‚Äî one of their most trusted bowlers at the death ‚Äî lost his rhythm when it mattered the most. Tasked with bowling the final over, Sandeep‚Äôs six legal deliveries stretched into a chaotic 11-ball over: Wd 0 Wd Wd Wd N1 4 6 1 1 1 ‚Äî a rare meltdown from the usually reliable pacer.Delhi Capitals finished their innings at 188/5, and the mood in their camp was upbeat. Smiles lit up their dugout, with players clearly satisfied with what looked like a competitive total.Opener Abishek Porel, who set the tone early with the bat, sounded confident in the mid-innings chat with the broadcasters."The plan was to go hard in the powerplay which would make it easier later on. If you bowl slower, it is helpful on this wicket and hopefully our bowlers do well. A very good total on this wicket," he said.But Rajasthan Royals had other ideas.They came out all guns blazing, dismantling Delhi‚Äôs bowling attack from the outset. Yashasvi Jaiswal set the tone with a brisk 51, while Sanju Samson, before retiring hurt on 31, ensured the momentum stayed firmly in Rajasthan‚Äôs corner.And then came Nitish Rana, who played a stunning knock of 51 off 28 balls to give a big home but star pacer Starc pulled things back in Delhi's favour.When the match headed into a Super Over, Sandeep found himself in the spotlight once again ‚Äî a chance at redemption after a forgettable final over.But pressure mounted, and history repeated itself.Sandeep struggled to hold his nerve, failing to apply any real pressure. Delhi Capitals chased down the target in just four deliveries, sealing a memorable win and leaving Sandeep with another tough outing to reflect on."Bhaiya, plain t-shirt hai ya kissi player ke naam wali jersey?" ‚Äî a curious fan asked a t-shirt vendor stationed outside the Arun Jaitley Stadium, just an hour and a half before the Delhi Capitals vs Rajasthan Royals clash.The seller replied, "Sirf KL Rahul ki hai." One fan bought it. Then another. Soon, a line of eager customers formed, each asking for different sizes, as the buzz around KL Rahul gripped the scene outside the stadium.Interestingly, the jersey bore the Delhi Capitals colours, but had "KL Rahul" and the number 01 printed on the back ‚Äî a curious sight, yet a clear sign of the mania surrounding the star batter.Inside the Kotla, it was a vibrant sea of blue and red.The atmosphere reached a crescendo when the stadium DJ dropped the "Dilli re, Roar Macha!" anthem ‚Äî and right on cue, KL Rahul cleared his front leg to send a slot ball from Tushar Deshpande soaring over long-off. The crowd erupted.Rahul's knock was entertaining, albeit not blistering. He scored 38 runs off 32 deliveries before falling to Jofra Archer ‚Äî notably, the first time Archer managed to dismiss Rahul in IPL history.And he showed his composure in the Super Over too, delivering under pressure and giving fans a treat to watch."We perhaps got too casual in the middle phase," admitted Axar Patel after Delhi Capitals‚Äô unbeaten run was halted by Mumbai Indians in their previous outing.Before the clash against Rajasthan Royals, a quick glance at Axar's IPL 2025 stats painted a worrying picture: 67 runs, 0 wickets in 5 matches ‚Äî far from the impact expected from the captain and star allrounder.Trolled heavily for throwing his wicket away against Mumbai, Axar walked out to a mix of pressure and expectation. But amidst loud chants of "Bapu! Bapu!" echoing around the Kotla, he responded like a true leader ‚Äî smashing a fiery 34 off just 14 balls, laced with four boundaries and two sixes.The crowd, however, erupted when he made an impact with the ball. Coming in just when his team needed a breakthrough, Axar cleaned up Riyan Parag for 8 ‚Äî his first wicket of IPL 2025. The dismissal came at a crucial juncture, especially after Sanju Samson had to retire hurt on 31.Axar had finally delivered with both bat and ball ‚Äî and the Kotla faithful made sure he knew it.

MUMBAI: The BCCI ‚Äôs decision to carry out on-field inspections of bats has become a major talking point. The initiative commenced on Sunday with checks during the RR vs RCB and DC vs MI matches. Pictures of MI skipper Hardik Pandya‚Äôs bat undergoing a check went viral.However, on Tuesday, KKR players Sunil Narine and Anrich Nortje became the first to fail the gauge test. Reserve umpire Saiyed Khalid found Narine‚Äôs bat oversized before their chase against PBKS. A video shows Narine with Angkrish Raghuvanshi near the dugout during inspection, where Raghuvanshi‚Äôs bat passed through the gauge but Narine‚Äôs didn‚Äôt.Forced to change his bat, a distracted Narine was dismissed for five runs by Marco Jansen. Similarly, debutant Nortje‚Äôs bat too failed the gauge test. However, he remained at the non-striker‚Äôs end and didn‚Äôt take strike. SRH head coach Daniel Vettori downplayed the situation on Wednesday at the Wankhede Stadium, noting regular bat compliance checks occur in dressing rooms.‚ÄúI wish they‚Äôd checked the bats when I was playing,‚Äù he joked. ‚ÄúThe umpires go through the dressing rooms a lot of the time, so guys know that their bats are compliant. It‚Äôll reset anyone trying to have a bigger bat, but it‚Äôs pretty easy to get your bat through that cage.‚Äù He acknowledged bat evolution as natural progression, citing manufacturers‚Äô ability to create larger yet lightweight bats. Will bat sizes be reduced in the future to give bowlers more of a chance in the game? ‚ÄúI mean, everyone seems to enjoy sixes and fours.I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre going to get a reduction in bat size and it doesn‚Äôt really worry me,‚Äù Vettori stated. However, Paras Anand, CEO of Meerut-based Sanspareils Greenlands (SG), a wellknown bat manufacturer, feels that the Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC), the custodians of the laws of the game, and the ICC must look at other areas to restore balance.‚ÄúModern-day players practise hitting sixes. Cricket is not what it was 15 years ago. There are other ways of achieving balance between bat and ball, like churning out sporting pitches, using a ball that swings a bit more, or increasing the size of the boundaries. A 1 mm or 2 mm increase in the size of the bats won‚Äôt make a difference,‚Äù Anand told TOI.Current IPL rules state: ‚ÄúThe blade of the bat must not exceed the following dimensions: width 4.25 in or 10.8 cm, depth 2.64 in or 6.7 cm, edge 1.56 in or 4 cm. Moreover, it must be able to pass through a bat gauge.‚Äù
Article Summary: KKR's Sunil Narine and Anrich Nortje fail the 'gauge test' during their match against Punjab Kings. The initiative commenced on Sunday with checks during the RR vs RCB and DC vs MI matches. Pictures of MI skipper Hardik Pandya‚Äôs bat undergoing a check went viral.
